title: The cloudburst is upon us: Cloud-software stocks suffering worst declines on record; Atlassian , Twilio stocks both shed a third of their value Friday on their worst day yet, and other cloud-software declines are sending ETFs tracking the industry to their worst week on record amid forecasts that show slowing growth
text:
The First Trust Cloud Computing ETF SKYY, the Global X Cloud Computing ETF CLOU, and the WisdomTree Cloud Computing Fund WCLD fell as much as 5% Friday, with the latter two heading for their worst week on record; the The First Trust Cloud Computing ETF was on track for its second-worst week on record, after a 12.6% decline in the week ending Aug. 19, 2011.

Leading the race for the bottom for cloud-software were shares of Atlassian Inc. TEAM and Twilio TWLO, which were both easily heading for their worst day ever having both shed a third or more of their value in Friday trading. Late Thursday, Atlassian execs said customers were converting to paid subscriptions from freemium versions at a slower pace. Twilio caught a two-notch downgrade from BofA Securities analyst Michael Funk before the company forecast a poor outlook.

Companies like Atlassian and Twilio were seen as a strong bet heading into a recession, as cloud software can help to reduce costs from legacy software as well as create efficiencies within organizations. Raymond James analyst Adam Tindle, in detailing the read-throughs on Atlassian's report, explained how that view is now changing on Wall Street.

Atlassian's results "suggest even the most diversified, low cost, visible growth models (cloud transition) are not immune to this brutal macro environment and shares are de-rating accordingly," they wrote.

"We do see the cloud transition as a 'when not if' and pricing incentives to move existing customer to Cloud will create an uplift upon renewals, but we have concerns around 70% of Cloud customers being on monthly plans that are easy to turn off if economic distress continues," Tindle continued, while maintaining a "market perform" rating.

The declines bled over to the largest cloud-software names as well Friday, even as most have yet to report earnings this season. Salesforce Inc. CRM shares fell 6%, and were headed for their worst week since August 2011, and Service Now Inc. NOW shares declined 7% and were headed for their worst week since February 2016. Shares of Okta Inc. OKTA fell 10%, Snowflake Inc. SNOW shares fell 12%, MongoDB Inc. MDB shares dropped 8%, and Workday Inc. WDAY shares fell 6%.

Meanwhile, shares of cybersecurity company Cloudflare Inc. NET dropped as much as 20% following earnings late Thursday, pulling down other names in the space like Palo Alto Networks Inc. PANW, Zscaler Inc. ZS, and CrowdStrike Holdings Inc. CRWD. Fortinet Inc. FTNT kicked off that decline Thursday, after forecasting fourth-quarter billings late Wednesday that undershot analysts' expectations, sending shares down nearly 14% in Thursday trading. Fortinet's stock was on track for its worst week since October 2015, according to FactSet records.

Cybersecurity stocks specifically were heading for their worst week in 2Â½ years, with the ETFMG Prime Cyber Security ETF HACK down more than 10%, its worst since a 13% drop the week ended March 13,2020. The First Trust Nasdaq Cybersecurity ETF CIBR was down nearly 11%, also on track for its worst week since early 2020.

Of the various cloud-computing ETFs year to date, CIBR is faring best with a 29% drop, and WCLD is performing the worst with a 55% drop, compared with a 22% fall on the S&P 500 index SPXand a 34% drop in the Nasdaq Composite Index. COMP
